G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as it is a civil action for damages exceeding $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue properly lies in Middlesex County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this action occurred within this County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the premises, owed Plaintiff, a lawful business invitee, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain the premises in a safe condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by possessors of land to all lawful entrants. Although the excerpt provided is only a concurrence focused on the treatment of trespassers, the majority opinion clearly holds that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors, which necessarily encompasses lawful business invitees. Thus, the case does support the proposition, even if the quoted passage does not itself state it.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: We hold, therefore, that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The duty owed by an occupier of land is the same to all lawful visitors: to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant had a duty to inspect its aisles, displays, and shelving to prevent foreseeable harm to customers.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case deals with a fall on a stairway in a subway station, not with aisles, displays, or shelving, and its core discussion is about premises liability for foreign substances and the time element needed to impute constructive notice. While the opinion recites the general duty of a possessor of business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe, it does not articulate a specific affirmative duty to inspect aisles, displays, or shelving as framed in the proposition. Thus, using this case as authority for a specific duty to inspect such store fixtures overstates what the opinion holds.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: 1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. Rossley v. S. S. Kresge Co. 339 Mass. 654, 656. Coates v. First Natl. Stores Inc. 322 Mass, 563, 565. Vance v. Gould, 355 Mass. 104, 105.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant had a duty to inspect its aisles, displays, and shelving to prevent foreseeable harm to customers.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case deals with premises liability for snow and ice in a parking lot, not inspection duties for store aisles, displays, or shelving. Its holding is that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to address dangers from snow and ice, abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. It does not discuss or impose any specific duty to inspect interior store areas like aisles or shelving, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.”

Zinck v. Wal-Mart Stores East, LP, 2019.raw_text: Zinck v. Wal-Mart Stores East, LP, 2019 Mass. Super. LEXIS 53 (Super. Ct. 2019)
Zinck v. Wal-Mart Stores East, LP, 2019.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable to Defendant that an unsecured box could fall from height and cause injury.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s physical injuries and resulting damages.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion does not decide any issue about whether a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s physical injuries. The court explicitly notes that negligence and causation are assumed for purposes of the certified questions, and the substance of the decision concerns whether Massachusetts recognizes certain emotional distress and prenatal injury claims, plus market-share liability. It therefore provides no authority on proximate cause of physical injuries as stated in the proposition.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540 (19.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress." (386 Mass. at 545)

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a store owner owes a nondelegable duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, which extends to the arrangement of merchandise displays.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki concerns a residential landlord’s duty of reasonable care to tenants and their guests regarding defects in leased premises; it does not deal with store owners, commercial premises, or merchandise displays. The opinion’s discussion of premises liability and nondelegable duties is confined to the landlord-tenant context and statutory provisions governing landlords, so it cannot be cited as authority for a store owner’s nondelegable duty to arrange merchandise safely.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.”

Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a store owner owes a nondelegable duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, which extends to the arrangement of merchandise displays.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).support_reasoning: The case concerns a residential landlord’s duty to maintain common areas (a porch and exterior stairs) for a tenant, not a store owner’s duty to customers or the arrangement of merchandise displays. The court articulates the landlord’s duty of reasonable care in common areas and discusses a building code violation as evidence of negligence, but it does not address premises liability in the retail context or any nondelegable duty of a store owner regarding merchandise displays. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendants violated a duty which they owed to her as their tenant with respect to areas used by her in common with other occupants of the building. The duty of the defendants was ‘to use reasonable care to keep the common areas in as good a condition as that in which they were or appeared to be at the time of the creation of the tenancy.’"

Cruz v. Dune, 2018 Mass. App. Div. 45 (2.raw_text: Cruz v. Dune, 2018 Mass. App. Div. 45 (2018)
Cruz v. Dune, 2018 Mass. App. Div. 45 (2.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a store owner owes a nondelegable duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, which extends to the arrangement of merchandise displays.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts also provides that negligent failure to maintain a safe premises constitutes tortious conduct for which damages may be recovered.

Beaulieu v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 164 Mass.raw_text: Beaulieu v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 164 Mass. 475 (1895)
Beaulieu v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 164 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff reasonably relied upon Defendant to maintain its premises in a safe condition while she was shopping.
Beaulieu v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 164 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a dispute over a covenant against encumbrances and the measure of damages arising from a right-of-way encumbrance and related prior litigation. It does not involve a plaintiff shopping on a defendant’s premises, nor any discussion of a shopper’s reasonable reliance on a property owner or occupier to maintain premises in a safe condition. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about reliance while shopping.
Beaulieu v. Lynn & Boston R.R., 164 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s claim is, that the land conveyed to him by the defendant’s deed was on its southerly boundary subject to a right of way in favor of other persons. The suit is maintained on the covenant against encumbrances. The suits of Starkie and Green v. Richmond were suits in equity to compel the defendant therein, who is the plaintiff in the present suit, to tear down a building which he had erected…”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: As a further result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred special damages including medical bills in the approximate amount of $2,500, lost wages of $1,200, and will continue to incur further medical expenses and related damages.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: As a further result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred special damages including medical bills in the approximate amount of $2,500, lost wages of $1,200, and will continue to incur further medical expenses and related damages.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the plaintiff’s recovery of specific special damages (medical bills of $2,500, lost wages of $1,200, and future medical expenses). Dos Santos v. Coleta does not address or establish any rule about the measure, type, or pleading of special damages; it only notes that the plaintiff’s medical expenses exceeded $700,000 in the factual background. The case is about premises liability and the open and obvious danger doctrine, not about quantifying or proving special damages, so it does not support the cited damages proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was hospitalized for an extended period of time following the accident, and in the years since, he has been hospitalized at various facilities for medical conditions related to his quadriplegia. His medical bills and related expenses exceeded $700,000 at the time of trial.”

Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197.raw_text: Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197 Mass. 512 (1908)
Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover her damages under well-established Massachusetts tort law.
Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197.case_name: Sullivan v. Old Colony Street Railway Co.
Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197.support_reasoning: The opinion does not announce any broad rule that the plaintiff is entitled to recover her damages under well‑established Massachusetts tort law. Instead, it tightens and limits recoverable damages by holding that the plaintiff may not recover for mental suffering arising from contemplation of a later‑conceived child’s death, deeming such damages too remote. The court sustains the defendant’s exceptions and rejects that element of recovery, so the case does not support the cited general proposition of entitlement to recover damages.
Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 197.relevant_excerpt: "She was thus permitted to recover money compensation for the sorrow and anguish endured as a result of the contemplation of the death of her child conceived nearly seven months and born fourteen months after the injury. This is extending the rule of damages beyond any limits heretofore recognized. It is an expansion which finds no support in any principle of law. ... The mental suffering, for which damages can be recovered, therefore, is limited to that which results to the person injured as the necessary or natural consequence of the physical injury."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: B. For costs and interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
